abstract.p: Ken Schellenberg letter says he shares Ward Connerly's dismay (May 8 Op-Ed) that some large bookstores have 'separate but equal' sections for African-American authors

block.p: Re ''Where 'Separate but Equal' Still Rules'' Op-Ed, May 8):
I share Ward Connerly's dismay that some large bookstores have ''separate but equal'' sections for African-American authors, and I have often complained to my local store manager about this.
Re ''Where 'Separate but Equal' Still Rules'' Op-Ed, May 8):
I share Ward Connerly's dismay that some large bookstores have ''separate but equal'' sections for African-American authors, and I have often complained to my local store manager about this.

Gay literature is also segregated in this bookstore, but arbitrarily (Jean Genet and Jeannette Winterson are ''fiction and literature'' while Edmund White and Gertrude Stein are of ''gay and lesbian interest'').

The absurdity of multiple categories for literature is perhaps best illustrated by the case of James Baldwin, whose novel ''Giovanni's Room'' is about two gay white men in Paris. It is (of course?) filed in the African-American section.
People do not fit into neat little clear-cut categories. Neither do books.
